reference.title: Typewriter Anatomy Definitions
reference.shortdesc: Typewriter anatomy includes the internal and external mechanisms and accessories that work together to make a functioning typewriter.

dlentry.dd: The outer shell of a typewriter which protects the internal mechanisms.
Screws connecting the body panels to the interior typewriter machinery.
The large mechanical shaft that holds the platen and feed rollers, moving horizontally across the machine as you type.
A small lever on the right-hand side of the typewriter, next to the right-hand platen knob, that centers the carriage when activated.
A large lever located on the left-hand side of the carriage that moves the carriage to the left-hand margin and advances your typing paper to the next line.
A small, rubber roller that works in conjunction with the platen to grip and guide your typing paper.
A lever located on the left-hand side of the carriage that sets the vertical distance between lines of text.
A lever that allows you to manually change the winding direction of the ink ribbon between.
A key that allows the user to temporarily type past preset margin stops. Often denoted as "MAR-REL."
Small tabs on the carriage used to set margins. The tabs act as stoppers and prevent the carriage from moving beyond a set margin space.
A metal bar that holds typing paper against the platen.
Small rubber rollers on the paper bail that press the paper against the platen roller.
An adjustable clamp that holds paper against the platen roller, used in conjunction with a paper bail.
A lever that, when activated, releases pressure from the feed rollers, allowing the typing paper to be removed.
A flat surface being the platen that holds paper perpendicular against the platen.
A small shaft protruding from the left-hand platen knob, connecting to a metal shaft that holds the platen.
A circular handle at each end of the platen which rotates the platen.
A lever on the right-hand side of the typewriter, unlocking the platen from the typewriter when pressed.
A rubber roller in front of the carriage, holding and guiding paper as you type.
A lever that shifts the ribbon up and down, allowing ink transfer of a different color.
The metal lid protecting the internal ribbon mechanisms, often hinged or connected via prongs and grommets.
A thin metal plate, located on the typewriter undercarriage directly under the segment.
Character tabs that activate the type bars when pressed.
The small rubber pads on the bottom of a typewriter, preventing sliding and absorbing vibrations.
The underside of the typewriter.
A pronged lever that automatically changes the ribbon winding direction during typing.
A linear guide mechanism that slides the carriage along the horizontal plane of the rail.
A string connecting the carriage to the mainspring drum.
Small rings that cover holes in the typewriter frame where structural components connect.
A metal arm connecting Type Keys to a Type Bar/Hammer.
A tightly coiled spring, maintaining tension to move the carriage as needed.
A ring-like mechanism at the end of the platen shaft/rod.
A mechanism holding the ribbon guides and lifting the ribbon to meet the type bar when a key is struck, transferring ink onto the typing paper.
Small slots that hold and straighten the ribbon.
A small opening on the Ribbon Spool that sits over the Spool Pin.
A cylindrical reel containing inked ribbon.
A comb-like mechanism that guides the typebars to ensure proper character alignment. Also known as the type basket.
Metal cylinder that contains the mainspring, also known as the Spring Drum.
The group of gears, barrels/drums, and other mechanics that hold the mainspring in the typewriter.
A small pin that aligns the ribbon spool with the ribbon shaft.
A small rod that holds and rotates the ribbon spool.
A thin, metal bar that holds type slugs at its end and strikes the ink ribbon to print text.
Mechanical connection between the Keylever and Type Bar.
Metal characters located at the end of a Type Bar.
A small spring, wrapped into a circle, that sits between the platen roller and platen shaft collar, allowing manual spacing adjustment.
